TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, magnesic, frigid Vitrandic Haploxeralfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Kenotrail silt loam on a 39 percent southeast facing slope at an elevation of 3,570 feet, under a mixed Douglas-fir-ponderosa pine canopy.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.)
O--2 inches to 0; needles, cones, bark, twigs, and partially decomposed organic matter.
A--0 to 4 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) silt loam, dark brown (7.5YR 3/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and common fine roots; 10 percent pebbles; neutral (pH 6.6); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
BA--4 to 9 inches; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) silt loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic, many very fine and fine roots, few common roots; 10 percent pebbles; slightly acid (pH 6.4); clear wavy boundary.  (2 to 6 inches thick)
Bt1--9 to 19 inches; reddish yellow (7.5 YR 6/6) gravelly silty clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few thin clay films on ped faces and in pores; common very fine and fine roots, few medium roots; 15 percent pebbles; neutral (pH 6.6); clear smooth boundary. (4 to 14 inches thick)
Bt2--19 to 32 inches; reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) gravelly silty clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few thin clay films on ped faces and in pores; common fine and few very fine roots; 30 percent pebbles and 20 percent weathered pebble-size talc fragments; neutral (pH 6.6); abrupt smooth boundary.  (8 to 20 inches thick).
Cr--32 inches, partially decomposed talc.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Colville Indian Reservation; Ferry County, Washington; about 13 miles northeast of the town of Keller; 300 feet east and 950 feet north of the southwest corner of sec. 25, T. 32 N., R. 33 E., W.M.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature at a depth of 20 inches is 44 to 46 degrees F.  These soils are usually moist but are dry in all parts between a depth of 4 and 12 inches for 60 to 75 consecutive days.  The upper 7 to 14 inches has an estimated moist bulk density of
1.35 to 1.50 g/cc, volcanic glass content of 5 to 20 percent, acid-oxalate extractable aluminum plus one-half of the acid-oxalate extractable iron of 0.4 to 1.0 percent, and 15-bar water retention of 5 to 10 percent for air dried samples.   Solum thickness and depth to a paralithic contact with weathered talc range from 20 to 40 inches.  The particle-size control section is 18 to 35 percent clay and 15 to 35 percent pebbles.  Reaction is slightly acid or neutral.
The A horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 5 moist or dry.  It has 5 to 15 percent pebbles.
The Bt horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 5YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 4 through 6 moist or dry.  It is silty clay loam or clay loam and is 15 to 35 percent pebbles and 15 to 30 percent weathered pebble-size talc fragments.  There are few thin to moderately thick clay films on ped faces and lining pores.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Nahahum, Nardmont and Panak series.  Nahahum, Nardmont and Panak soils are more than 40 inches deep to bedrock.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Kenotrail soils are on ridges and shoulders of mountains.  These soils formed in residuum derived primarily from serpentine, greenstone, talc and other metaigneous rock with a surface admixture of volcanic ash and loess.  Slopes are 20 to 40 percent.  Elevations range from 3,200 to 3,800 feet.  The average annual precipitation is 18 to 22 inches.  The mean January temperature is about 23 degrees F, mean July temperature is about 65 degrees F, and the mean annual air temperature is about 43 degrees F.  The frost-free season is 90 to 120 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Hartill, Oxerine, Scoap, and Thout soils.  Hartill, Oxerine, Scoap and Thout soils are loamy-skeletal.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained, medium to rapid runoff; permeability is moderate in the upper part and moderately slow in the lower part of the solum.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Timber production, livestock grazing, wildlife habitat, watershed, and recreation are the principal uses.  The native vegetation is Douglas-fir, ponderosa pine, and western larch with an understory of pinegrass, bluebunch wheatgrass, sweetscented bedstraw, spreading sweetroot, Hook violet, common snowberry, Saskatoon serviceberry, heartleaf arnica, silky lupine, dwarf rose and kinnikinnick.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  North central Washington.  The series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Colville Indian Reservation; Ferry County, Washington, 1987.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this soil are an ochric epipedon from the surface to 4 inches and an argillic horizon from 9 to 32 inches.  A paralithic contact with weathered talc is at 32 inches.  The particle-size control section averages 18 percent hard rock fragments.  The description reflects a change in classification due to Andisols, from fine-loamy, serpentinitic, frigid Mollic Haploxeralfs to fine-loamy, serpentinitic, frigid Vitrandic Haplxoeralfs.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
